docs.lead_paragraph: Readers offer ideas for tax reform but doubt it will happen.
docs.abstract: Sunday dialogue on income tax reform and whether it is likely to happen.

docs.lead_paragraph: The court debate over the new health care law offers yet another example of worrying about imaginary risks.

headline.seo: Slippery-Slope Logic vs. Health Care Law - Economic View
headline.main: Slippery-Slope Logic, Applied to Health Care
headline.print_headline: Slippery-Slope Logic, Applied to Health Care

docs.abstract: Richard H Thaler Economic View column contends the Supreme Court deliberations over the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act offer yet another example of worrying about imaginary risks; opines one pernicious category of such risks involves those created by proponents of the 'slippery slope' arguments; concludes such arguments are dangerous because they are popular, versatile and often convincing--yet completely fallacious.
docs.snippet: The court debate over the new health care law offers yet another example of worrying about imaginary risks.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A computer program developed at I.B.M. uses game techniques and psychology to influence dieting: eat a salad, for example, and you could win 50 cents.

headline.seo: An I.B.M. Computer Program Rewards Healthy Diets
headline.main: Dieting for Dollars (or Maybe a Movie Ticket)
headline.print_headline: Dieting for Dollars (or Maybe a Movie Ticket)

docs.abstract: Nicole LaPorte Prototype column on IBM inventor Michael Paolini, who was part of a group behind company's new patent for a computerized system that tracks food intake and rewards good choices; notes the system, which uses game techniques and psychology, may eventually help companies and insurers encourage healthier habits among their employees.
docs.snippet: A computer program developed at I.B.M. uses game techniques and psychology to influence dieting: eat a salad, for example, and you could win 50 cents.

docs.lead_paragraph: Efforts in Washington State to address a resurgent childhood ailment have been hobbled by years of recession-induced budget cuts that have hollowed out public health departments.

headline.seo: Whooping Cough Epidemic Hits Washington State
headline.main: Cutbacks Hurt a State’s Response to Whooping Cough
headline.print_headline: Budget Cuts Hurt Washington State’s Response to Whooping Cough Outbreak

docs.abstract: Efforts in Washington State to address a resurgent epidemic of whooping cough have been hobbled by years of recession-induced budget cuts that have reduced staff and eliminated preventive care programs at public health departments.
docs.snippet: Efforts in Washington State to address a resurgent childhood ailment have been hobbled by years of recession-induced budget cuts that have hollowed out public health departments.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The time has come for us to admit that psychiatric diagnosis is too important to be left exclusively in the hands of psychiatrists.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by psychiatrist Allen Frances contends that the upcoming fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders will introduce many new and unproven diagnoses that will result in a glut of unnecessary and harmful drug prescriptions; argues that the time has come to admit that the psychiatric manual is too important to be created by psychiatrists alone.
docs.snippet: The time has come for us to admit that psychiatric diagnosis is too important to be left exclusively in the hands of psychiatrists.

keywords.value: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Book)
keywords.name: creative_works

docs.lead_paragraph: Efforts by gays and lesbians to overcome the legal obstacles faced by same-sex couples, notably the Defense of Marriage Act, may best be fought in courtrooms.

headline.seo: Path to Same-Sex Marriage Probably Runs Through Courts
headline.main: Same-Sex Marriage Activists Look to Law
headline.print_headline: Same-Sex Marriage Activists Look to Law

docs.abstract: Tara Siegel Bernard Your Money column examines several court cases challenging the Defense of Marriage Act, 1996 federal law that defines marriage as between one man and one woman; contends that cases represent the best chance to address the long list of extra costs and legal hurdles faced by same-sex couples.
docs.snippet: Efforts by gays and lesbians to overcome the legal obstacles faced by same-sex couples, notably the Defense of Marriage Act, may best be fought in courtrooms.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Revisions to a major psychiatric manual would expand recognized addiction symptoms, which could pose huge consequences for insurers and taxpayers.

headline.seo: D.S.M. Revisions May Sharply Increase Addiction Diagnoses
headline.main: Addiction Diagnoses May Rise Under Guideline Changes
headline.print_headline: New Guidelines May Sharply Increase Addiction Diagnoses

docs.abstract: Psychiatrists and other specialists rewriting the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders want to expand the list of recognized symptoms for drug and alcohol addiction, while also reducing the number of symptoms required for a diagnosis; revisions could have huge consequences for insurers and taxpayers.
docs.snippet: Revisions to a major psychiatric manual would expand recognized addiction symptoms, which could pose huge consequences for insurers and taxpayers.

keywords.value: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Book)
keywords.name: creative_works

docs.lead_paragraph: Days before revelations of JPMorgan Chase's $2 billion trading loss rocked Wall Street, the company's always-confident chief executive, Jamie Dimon, was his usual exuberant self. When the bosses of six of the largest banks gathered at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in downtown Manhattan to meet with a top Fed governor, the others used the underground garage and avoided the cameras. Mr. Dimon came and went through the front door, and even chatted with a CNBC reporter.

headline.main: The Bet That Blew Up For Chase: A Huge Loss Stains Dimon, One of Banking's Top Risk Managers

docs.abstract: JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon's sterling reputation has been tarnished by the bank's $2 billion trading loss; Dimon was widely credited for steering JPMorgan through the financial crisis, and for having a highly evolved sense of risk management. Photos (M)

byline.original: By NELSON D. SCHWARTZ and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical costs continue to loom large over retirement, a report from Fidelity Investments says. A 65-year-old couple retiring this year without any employer-based health coverage would need an estimated $240,000 to cover medical costs through retirement, according to Fidelity's latest estimate. That's a 4 percent increase from last year's figure. (The number has increased by 50 percent since 2002, when Fidelity first calculated the cost at $160,000.)
docs.abstract: Bucks blog; Fidelity Investments estimates that a 65-year-old couple retiring in 2012 without any employer-based health coverage would need $240,000 to cover their medical costs through retirement, a 4 percent increase from the 2011 figure. Photo (M)0
